dc:description: *FOXI3* was first reported in relation to autosomal dominant T-cell immunodeficiency in 2022 (Ghosh et al., PMID: 35987349). T-cell immunodeficiency is a broad classification of disorders that affect the cell-mediated aspects of the immune response, wherein circulating numbers of T lymphocytes are decreased or ineffective. At least 2 variants (nonsense) have been reported in humans. Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level data and experimental data. Variants in *FOXI3* have been reported in individuals with the following disease entities:  T-cell immunodeficiency and Craniofacial microsomia 2. Per criteria outlined by the Clingen Lumping and Splitting Working Group, we found a difference in phenotypic variability. Therefore, the following disease entities have been split into multiple disease entities, T-cell immunodeficiency (MONDO:0003780) and Craniofacial microsomia 2 (MONDO:0958194). The split curation for Craniofacial microsomia 2 will be assessed separately. Variants in this gene have been reported in at least 2 probands in 1 publication (PMID: 35987349). The mechanism for disease is haploinsufficiency (PMID: 35987349). This gene-disease relationship is supported by knockout and variant mouse models presenting with absence or decreased weight of thymus (. PMID: 31600545, PMID: 37041148). In summary, there is limited evidence to support the relationship between *FOXI3* and T-cell immunodeficiency. Although more evidence is needed to support a causal role, no convincing evidence has emerged that contradicts the gene-disease relationship. This classification was approved by the ClinGen SCID-CID GCEP on the meeting date August 21st 2025 (SOP Version 11).

evidence.dc:description: The mice do have decreased thymus weights, indicating Foxi3 potentially plays an important role in thymic development. This also could explain altered T cell development seen in patients. However, there is no further evidence shown regarding any phenotypes related to T cells. The mouse models are specific to variants found in humans.

The mouse with the F218L variant does not have a thymus, similar to the Foxi3 knockout model. This lack of thymus development could suggest that patients with Foxi3 variants also have altered thymus development, leading to the altered T cell levels seen.
evidence.rdfs:label: Mao_MouseVariants

evidence.dc:description: Flow cytometry showed no difference in CD3+, CD4+, or CD8+ cells and there are also no differences in normalized TRECs in the thymus or spleen. These are the major phenotypes seen in patients with variants in FOXI3, casting some doubt on the connection.
These mice have decreased thymus weights, potentially indicating that Foxi3 plays an important role in thymic development, which could explain the altered T cell development seen in patients.
evidence.rdfs:label: Bernstock_Foxi3KO

evidence.dc:description:
Only genotyped 407 genes, some of which did have variants. Specifically, a variant c.293C>T was detected in BCL11B. BCL11B variants have been associated with TCL, but the phenotypic spectrum is broad and includes neurological, skeletal, and dysmorphic features (which were absent in this proband). This variant was reported in 218 alleles in gnomAD v3, so it is unlikely to be pathogenic but it remains unclear if it may be modifying the TCL. 

Additionally, the gene panel did not include UNC119, the gene with a variant in the other proband. 

Furthermore, it is unclear how the father was genotyped. The father did have the variant but was clinically unaffected.
Dual luciferase assay in HEK293T cells show the variant has no transcriptional activity compared to wild type FOXI3

Two siblings and the father have the same variant but are all clinically unaffected. Additionally, several other variants were found, specifically a heterozygous c.226C>T (p.Leu76Phe) in UNC119, which is a gene that has been reported to be associated with diminished T cell responses to TCR stimulation, CD4+ T cell lymphopenia, and infections in a single patient.
Dual luciferase assay in HEK293T cells show that this variant has no transcriptional activity compared to wild-type FOXI3

member.rdfs:label: Ghosh_F2P1
member.detectionMethod: Clinical primary immunodeficiency gene panel, consisting of 407 genes that included all known SCID genes and candidate genes. Never stated how the parents and siblings were genotyped, though a pedigree chart shows their genotypes. Additionally, not stated to be confirmed with Sanger sequencing.

evidence.dc:description: There is only 1 segregation and as this is an autosomal dominant condition, it should not be included in the final calculation.
evidence.rdfs:label: Ghosh_F1

member.rdfs:label: Ghosh_F1P1
member.detectionMethod:
Described the sequencing as "Research-based genome sequencing" but did not specify if it was exome or whole genome. 

Sanger sequencing confirmed the variants reported which met CLIA/CAP requirements.
